3) Certain nutrients are considered "essential" in the diets of some animals because
options: A) only those animals use those nutrients.
B) the nutrients are subunits of important polymers.
C) these animals are not able to synthesize these nutrients.
D) the nutrients are necessary coenzymes.
E) only certain foods contain them.

front: 4) To maintain adequate nutrition, animals require dietary access to certain amino acids. An amino acid that is referred to as "nonessential" would be best described as one that
options: A) can be made by the animal's body from other substances.
B) is not used by the animal in biosynthesis.
C) must be ingested in the diet.
D) is not readily absorbed by the gastrointestinal tract.
E) is not found in many proteins.

front: 5) Which pair correctly associates a physiological process with the appropriate vitamin?
options: A) blood clotting and vitamin C
B) normal vision and vitamin A
C) synthesis of cell membranes and vitamin D
D) protection of skin from cancer and vitamin E
E) production of white blood cells and vitamin K

7) Which pair correctly associates a biochemical process with the appropriate mineral associated with its use in animals?
options: A) maintenance of bone and calcium
B) cofactor in enzymes that make ATP and magnesium
C) thyroid hormone synthesis and iron
D) nucleic acid synthesis and sulfur

front: 8) A general rule relating the capacity of a specific animal's digestive system to provide adequate access to substrates for biosynthesis of cellular components, as well as fuel molecules needed for ATP production, is that the animal should have access to
options: B) a diet low in lipids and high in protein.
C) a low-calorie diet with a large intake of fluids, especially water.
D) a diet that matches the "food pyramid" for the species.
E) a diet that maximizes vitamins and minerals.

front: Use the following table showing the contents of a multivitamin supplement and its percentage of recommended daily values (DV) to answer the following questions. 9) The most likely reason that some of the vitamins and minerals in this supplement are found at less than 100% is
options: A) that it would be chemically impossible to add more.
B) these vitamins and minerals are too large in size to reach 100%.
C) it is too easy to overdose on minerals such as phosphorus and calcium.
D) it is dangerous to overdose on fat-soluble vitamins such as A and K.
E) these supplements are meant for those who have been deprived of healthy foods.

Use the following table showing the contents of a multivitamin supplement and its percentage of recommended daily values (DV) to answer the following questions. 11) Folic acid supplements have become especially important for pregnant women because
options: A) folic acid supplies vitamins that only pregnant women can use.
B) the folic acid is stored in adipose tissue by pregnant women so supplements are needed to make more available in the circulation.
C) the fetus makes high levels of folic acid.
D) folic acid deprivation is associated with neural tube abnormalities in a fetus.
E) folic acid deprivation is a cause of heart abnormalities in a newborn.

front: Use the following table showing the contents of a multivitamin supplement and its percentage of recommended daily values (DV) to answer the following questions. 12) Excessive iron absorption and accumulation to toxic levels is associated with
options: B) a liver abnormality that results in a decreased number of red blood cells.
C) various forms of inherited or acquired anemia.
D) the genetic disorder known as hemochromatosis.

B) are excludible intracellular processes in most organisms.
C) add a water molecule to break bonds (hydrolysis).
D) require the presence of hydrochloric acid to lower the pH.
E) require ATP as an energy source.

front: 26) Upon activation by stomach acidity, the secretions of the parietal cells
options: A) initiate the digestion of protein in the stomach.
B) initiate the mechanical digestion of lipids in the stomach.
C) initiate the chemical digestion of lipids in the stomach.
E) delay digestion until the food arrives in the small intestine.

options: A) processing of fats does not require any digestive enzymes, whereas the processing of carbohydrates does.

D) most absorbed fat first enters the lymphatic system, whereas carbohydrates directly enter the blood.
E) fats, but not carbohydrates, are digested by bacteria before absorption.

front: 36) Historically inaccurate diagnosis of acid reflux disorders and gastric ulcers has been improved by
options: C) the diagnosis and treatment of H. pylori infection.

front: 37) A hiatal hernia that disrupts the functional relationship between the smooth muscle in the esophagus and that in the stomach would be most likely to increase the frequency of
options: B) premature entry of food into the duodenum.

front: 38) A significant contribution of intestinal bacteria to human nutrition is the benefit of bacterial
options: A) production of vitamins A and C.
B) generation of gases needed for elimination.
E) recovery of water from fecal matter.

front: 39) The cells that secrete acidic fluid in the stomach are
options: A) the chief cells of the stomach.
B) the parietal cells of the stomach.
C) not needed for the transformation of pepsinogen to pepsin.
D) in the lumen of the stomach.
E) adding secretions along the esophagus.

front: 40) Stomach cells are moderately well adapted to the acidity and protein-digesting activities in the stomach by having
options: A) a sufficient colony of H. pylori.
B) a thick, mucous secretion and active mitosis of epithelial cells.
C) a high level of secretion by chief cells.
D) a high level of secretion from parietal cells.
E) secretions enter the stomach from the pancreas.

44) Cattle are able to survive on a diet consisting almost entirely of plant material because
options: B) cattle, like rabbits, re-ingest their feces.
C) they manufacture all 15 amino acids out of sugars in the liver.
D) cattle saliva has enzymes capable of digesting cellulose.
E) they have cellulose-digesting, symbiotic microorganisms in chambers of their stomachs.

front: 45) Analysis of jawbones from the skeletal remains of a vertebrate animal reveal its dietary patterns owing to
options: A) the position of muscle attachment sites.
B) the prevalence of specific kinds of teeth.
C) the size of the mouth opening.
D) the evidence of food molecules still present.
E) whether the mouth is the most anterior structure.

front: 46) An enlarged cecum is typical of
options: A) rabbits, horses, and herbivorous bears.
C) tubeworms that digest via symbionts.
E) tapeworms and other intestinal parasites.

front: 47) Coprophagy, the nutrition-boosting ingestion of fecal material, is important for the nutritional balance of
options: E) very large animals, such as elephants.

front: 48) PKU (phenylketonuria) is a hereditary condition in which infants and young children who ingest the amino acid phenylalanine risk serious neurological damage. However, the risk of damage can be substantially reduced by the severe restriction of phenylalanine in the diet. Which of the following is the nutritional concept that forms the basis for this preventive treatment?
options: E) structural anatomy of the brain

front: 49) When the digestion and absorption of organic molecules results in more energy-rich molecules than are immediately required by an animal, the excess is
options: B) stored as starch in the liver.
C) stored as glycogen in the liver and muscles.
D) oxidized and converted to ATP.
E) hydrolyzed and converted to ADP.

front: 50) Hypoglycemia, or low levels of glucose in the blood of a healthy human, is "corrected" by a(n)
options: A) increase in the secretion of insulin.
B) increase in the secretion of glucagon.
C) increase in the secretion of both insulin and glucagon.
D) decrease in the secretion of both insulin and glucagon.
E) increase in the secretion of thyroid hormones.

front: 51) A fasting animal whose energy needs exceed those provided in its diet draws on its stored resources in which order?
options: A) fat, then glycogen, then protein
B) glycogen, then protein, then fat
C) liver glycogen, then muscle glycogen, then fat
D) muscle glycogen, then fat, then liver glycogen
E) fat, then protein, then glycogen

front: 52) Obesity in humans is most clearly linked to
options: A) type 1 diabetes and prostate cancer.
B) type 1 diabetes and breast cancer.
C) type 2 diabetes and muscle hypertrophy.
D) type 2 diabetes and cardiovascular disease.
E) type 2 diabetes and decreased appetite.

Mouse mutations can affect an animal's appetite and eating habits. The ob gene codes for a satiety factor, the hormone leptin. The db gene product, the leptin receptor, is required to respond to the satiety factor. 57) Leptin is a product of adipose cells. Therefore, a very obese mouse would be expected to have
options: A) increased gene expression of ob and decreased expression of db.
B) increased gene expression of db and decreased expression of ob.
C) decreased transcription of both ob and db.
D) mutation of ob or db.

front: Mouse mutations can affect an animal's appetite and eating habits. The ob gene codes for a satiety factor, the hormone leptin. The db gene product, the leptin receptor, is required to respond to the satiety factor. 58) Many obese humans produce normal or increased levels of leptin without satiety, so the search for healthy regulation of food intake should focus on
options: C) overexpression of the leptin receptor gene.
D) eliminating carbohydrates from the diet.
